skills.name: Identify a parallelogram when presented non-conventionally
Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape
Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length

explanations.A: Starting at A, moving 4 right and 2 up takes us to D. The same move from B takes us to C. This means that the lines AD and BC are parallel and equal to each other in length; therefore AB and DC are parallel and equal in length too. This means the shape is a parallelogram as it has 2 pairs of parallel sides. Starting at A again, 1 right and 3 down takes us to B. This length is not equal to the line AD, and so the shape cannot be a rhombus. This means only Tom is correct.
explanations.B: Remember a parallelogram only has to have two pairs of parallel sides. A rhombus also needs four sides of equal length.
explanations.C: Remember a parallelogram only has to have two pairs of parallel sides. A rhombus also needs four sides of equal length.
explanations.D: Remember a parallelogram only has to have two pairs of parallel sides. A rhombus also needs four sides of equal length. You can see whether the sides are parallel by looking at the horizontal distance and the vertical distance between the end points of each side. To test their length, you can see if these are the same all around the shape.

explanations.A: For line segment P, starting at (1, 1), move 2 right and 5 up takes us to (3, 6). For line segment Q, start at (3, 1) move 4 right and 2 up takes us to (7, 3). Comparing these; both move 2 but for line P, there is a move of 5, whereas it is only 4 on line Q. This means that line segment P is longer.
explanations.B: It's easiest to count how many places you move horizontally and vertically to look at distances. For example: to get from (1,1) to (3,6), we have moved 2 right and 5 up. Now compare that with line segment Q's points to find which is longest.
